potential_users.where_to_find: Google Maps search 'barbershop near me', filter for small shops with <50 reviews (larger shops likely already have systems)
potential_users.why: Owner-operated shops make fast decisions. Walk in, demo, walk out with a trial signup. This is the #1 acquisition channel.
potential_users.approach: In-person visit during quiet hours. Lead with: 'I built a booking tool where your clients don't need to download anything. Can I show you for 2 minutes?'
potential_users.expected_response_rate: 40-60% will give you 2 minutes. 15-25% will try a free trial.

potential_users.where_to_find: Instagram hashtags (#boothrentalbarber, #independentbarber), Facebook group 'Booth Renters & Suite Owners'
potential_users.why: These barbers need their OWN tools — they can't use the shop's system. Under-served by SQUIRE (which targets shop owners). Perfect niche for Timber.
potential_users.approach: Instagram DM after genuinely engaging with their content first. 'Love your work! Quick question — do your clients have to download an app to book with you?'
potential_users.expected_response_rate: 10-20% will respond to a genuine DM. 5% will try the product.

potential_users.type: Barbers complaining about current tools on Reddit/Facebook
potential_users.where_to_find: Search r/Barber, r/smallbusiness, Facebook groups for 'booking app', 'Fresha problems', 'Booksy issues'
potential_users.why: These are barbers actively in buying mode — they have a problem right now
potential_users.approach: Reply helpfully to their complaint. 'I had the same frustration, which is why I built [Timber]. Happy to give you free access to try it.'
potential_users.expected_response_rate: 20-30% for in-thread complaints. They're already looking for alternatives.

influencers.where_to_find: Instagram search #barberlife, look for barbers who post business content (not just haircut photos)
influencers.why: One popular barber showing Timber in their story could drive 50+ trial signups. Barbers follow barbers.
influencers.approach: Offer free lifetime account in exchange for an honest review. Don't ask for promotion — ask for feedback. If they like it, they'll share organically.
influencers.expected_response_rate: 5-10% will respond to a cold DM. Higher if you've engaged with their content first.
influencers.caveat: This only works AFTER you have a polished product and some social proof. Wave 2, not Wave 1.

partners.why: Every barber visits their supply store. A flyer or QR code at the register is free, persistent advertising.
partners.approach: Visit in person. 'I built a booking app for barbers. Could I leave some flyers? Happy to send any of your customers a discount.'
partners.expected_response_rate: 50%+ will say yes — it costs them nothing and helps their customers.

partners.why: New barbers choosing their first tools. Get them on Timber before they discover Booksy or Fresha.
partners.approach: Offer a free 'business tools for new barbers' workshop or just ask to present for 15 minutes
partners.expected_response_rate: Medium — schools may welcome guest speakers about business tools

media.why: Widely read by salon professionals. Getting featured or listed as a recommended tool drives qualified traffic.
media.approach: Submit a guest post or sponsor a feature. Pitch: 'New booking tool eliminates app downloads for clients'
media.expected_response_rate: Low for cold pitches. Better after you have 10+ users and a case study.

media.where_to_find: Search 'barbershop business tips' on YouTube, look for channels with 5K-50K subscribers
media.why: Barbers watch YouTube for business advice. A tool review from a trusted channel converts well.
media.approach: Offer free access + a small sponsorship ($100-200) for an honest review

community_leaders.where_to_find: Admin lists on Barber Nation, Barbers Talk, etc.
community_leaders.why: Group admins control what gets promoted and what gets deleted. Getting on their good side means your posts survive.
community_leaders.approach: Be a genuine contributor for 2-4 weeks. Then DM the admin: 'I've been helping in the group — I also built a booking tool for barbers. Would it be okay to share?'
community_leaders.expected_response_rate: High if you've been genuinely helpful first. Most admins appreciate contributors who add value.

messaging_angles.message_direction: 'Your clients hate downloading apps to book a haircut. What if they didn't have to?'
messaging_angles.when_to_use: Primary angle for all outreach. This is the differentiator. Lead with it always.
messaging_angles.works_best_on: Barbers who've heard clients complain about downloading Booksy or Fresha
messaging_angles.what_not_to_say: Don't trash-talk Booksy/Fresha by name. Compare the experience, not the brand.

messaging_angles.message_direction: 'You just need booking and payments. Not 47 features you'll never use.'
messaging_angles.when_to_use: For barbers frustrated with complex tools (Vagaro, Fresha's feature bloat)
messaging_angles.works_best_on: Solo barbers who feel overwhelmed by enterprise software
messaging_angles.what_not_to_say: Don't promise features you don't have. Be honest about what Timber does and doesn't do.

messaging_angles.message_direction: 'When something breaks, you talk to me — the person who built it. Not a chatbot.'
messaging_angles.when_to_use: For barbers who've had bad support experiences (very common with Booksy and Fresha)
messaging_angles.works_best_on: Barbers who recently complained about support in a group or review
messaging_angles.expected_response: Interest — personal attention is rare and valued
messaging_angles.what_not_to_say: Don't over-promise. Solo founder support scales badly — acknowledge you're small and position it as an advantage for now.

messaging_angles.message_direction: 'Try it free for 14 days. If it doesn't work for you, no hard feelings.'
messaging_angles.when_to_use: Closing angle — after generating interest, remove the risk
messaging_angles.works_best_on: Everyone — barbers are risk-averse with new tools
messaging_angles.what_not_to_say: Don't be pushy about the trial ending. Let the product sell itself.

weekly_target.facebook_group_engagement: 5 helpful posts/comments per week, 2-3 targeted DMs when natural
weekly_target.instagram_dms: 3-5 genuine DMs per week to barbers who post about booking frustrations

follow_up.after_demo: Text within 24 hours: 'Great meeting you — here's the link to try Timber. Any questions, text me.'
follow_up.after_trial_signup: Check in at day 3 and day 10. 'How's it going? Anything I can help with?'
follow_up.after_no_response: One follow-up after 5 days. If no response, move on. Don't be a pest.

expected_outcomes.in_person_demos: 20 demos → 5-8 trial signups → 1-3 paying customers (30-day cycle)
expected_outcomes.facebook_engagement: 4 weeks of value-first posting → recognised in 2-3 groups → 2-5 inbound inquiries
expected_outcomes.overall_30_day: 8-15 trial signups, 2-5 paying customers if product is good
expected_outcomes.overall_90_day: 30-50 trial signups, 10-20 paying customers, word-of-mouth beginning

dont_bother.why: They use enterprise solutions (Boulevard, Zenoti) and won't switch to an unknown solo-founder tool. Sales cycle is months with procurement committees.
Barbers are not on LinkedIn. You'll find salon software VENDORS, not customers.
Most independent barbers don't check business email regularly. They live on text, Instagram DMs, and Facebook. Cold email will have <1% open rate.

dont_bother.target: SaaS community outreach (r/SaaS, Indie Hackers, etc.)
dont_bother.why: These are your peers, not your customers. Great for emotional support, terrible for customer acquisition. You've already learned this.

dont_bother.target: PR / press outreach to tech publications
dont_bother.why: TechCrunch doesn't write about pre-revenue barber booking tools. Local barbershop publications might — but not until you have a story to tell.
